results.title: Metal makers
results.brief_description: A detailed examination of the mining and processing of copper, silver, lead and zinc at Mt. Isa, one of the world’s largest underground mines. Covers such aspects as the operation of the mine, mining techniques, mineral extractions and smelting, refining and distribution of the processed metal. Uses of the various metals are illustrated. Quality and pollution controls are also explained. The importance of Mt. Isa as a large inland city is also stressed.

results.title: Woolloomooloo
results.brief_description: A social and historical documentary on the redevelopment of one of Sydney’s oldest harbourside areas, from the initial plans of 1969 to the completion of the Housing Commission’s renovation project in late 1977. Details the roles of local, State and Federal governments, the State Planning Authority, The National Trust, the developers, the Builders’ Labourers Federation led by Jack Mundey, and the residents groups.

results.title: Mamadrama
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Arte, Zweites Deutsches Fernsehen and Amber Films
results.brief_description: An Australian documentary examining the portrayal of Jewish mothers on the big screen. From an early age filmmaker Monique Schwarz was puzzled by the discrepancy between the domineering and emasculating Jewish mothers typically represented on film, and her own mother, a Holocaust survivor. “Mamadrama” consequently has a strong personal touch, via the reflections of Schwarz and interviews with directors Paul Mazursky, Paul Bogart, and Larry Peerce, and actress Lainie Kazan. In addition to well-known Hollywood movies “Mamadrama” uses rare footage from early silent films, Yiddish language features and Israeli films. The tone of the documentary is reflective rather than critical; the most intriguing moments emerge from the candour with which the interviewees discuss their own mothers.

results.title: Dressing Dad
results.creator_credit: Sofya Gollan, Isabel Perez and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A short student film in which the filmmaker explores how the relationship with her father was transformed by the knowledge of his being a cross-dresser. Featuring interviews with her father and his transvestite friends, this work dispels many of the common preconceptions about cross-dressing and transvestitism while also being an engaging study of how families cope with aspects of individual difference and gender exploration.

results.title: Looking at plants
results.creator_credit: John Bird, Jim Harris and Swinburne Institute of Technology. Film and Television School
results.brief_description: Filmed in the Sherbrooke Forest Park, Australflora Nursery, Victoria, and shows glimpses of the plant and insect life which abound there. No narration, music only.

results.title: Telephones: using and abusing
results.creator_credit: Jennie Blackwood, E Brereton and Post Office Film Unit
results.brief_description: A dramatised account promoting speedy and efficient use of the telephone. Guides us in the correct methods of dialling, answering and speaking on the telephone. With animation explains the complex sequence of operations within an automatic exchange when a call is made.

results.title: 14's good, 18's better
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture
results.brief_description: A longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, now 18, intercut with footage from “Smokes and lollies”, shot when they were 14. Their previous expectations have been altered by the experiences of marriage, parenthood, employment, low incomes and insecurity. However, they remain optimistic, with their humour intact. (Awards: Winner, Best Australian Educational Short Film, Australian Teachers of Media (ATOM) Awards, 1982)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture
